titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Clavia Goodman papers, 1838-1970, undated 1997MS371
titlestmt.author: Ida Lucille Mangum

repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.abstract: The Clavia Goodman papers (dated 1856-1970; 10.88 cubic feet; 25 boxes) comprise letters, family records, manuscripts, printed materials, and negative photographs documenting the Goodman family while traveling and living in Cairo, Egypt, St. Ives, England, and Paris, Kentucky, during the early twentieth century.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by person, family, or format in five series: Clavia Goodman, Clay family, Dr. Cyril Goodman, Goodman family, Susan Elizabeth Clay Goodman, and Negatives.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Clavia Goodman was the daughter of Sue Clay Goodman (1880-1965) and Dr. Cyril Goodman (1870-1938). Sue Clay and Dr. Goodman married in 1902 and had two children, Laurie (1905-1906) and Clavia (1907-1970). Mrs. and Dr. Goodman met in London and soon moved to Egypt, where Dr. Goodman held the role of Deputy Director General in the Department of Health. Dr. Goodman also worked as a corps surgeon in the British army, and the Goodman family lived in Egypt for many years before he retired in 1918. After retiring, the entire family moved to Paris, Kentucky, where Sue's family lived.

Daughter of Cassius Marcellus Clay and Susan Elizabeth Clay Clay, Sue Clay Goodman was born in, and died in Kentucky. Her aunt was Laura Clay, a prominent figure in the women's suffrage movement, and one of the most important suffragists in the south. In 1946 Clavia published Bitter Harvest, a biography of Laura's suffrage work, which also contained an acknowledgements essay describing the interactions between people who personally knew Laura. In addition to the biography, Clavia authored many short stories, poems, and a longer manuscript titled Bluegrass Manners, none of which were published. Dr. Goodman was also a writer with many unpublished papers on current affairs, law, and medicine.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 1997MS371: [Identification of item], Clavia Goodman papers, 1856-1970, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clavia Goodman papers (dated 1856-1970; 10.88 cubic feet; 25 boxes) comprise letters, family records, manuscripts, printed materials, and negative photographs documenting the Goodman family while traveling and living in Cairo, Egypt, St. Ives, England, and Paris, Kentucky, during the early twentieth century. The bulk of the collection is letters to or from Clavia, Cyril, and Sue Goodman and relate news of family and friends living in Egypt, Europe, and America. The collection includes letters between Clay family members such as Brutus Junius Clay, Cassius M. Clay, Jr., Susan Elizabeth Clay Clay, of Paris, Kentucky and Anne Clay Shackelford, of Richmond, Kentucky. Many letters discuss life leading up to and during the First Second World Wars. The collection also includes diaries, drafts, and manuscripts written by individual members of the Goodman family and include short stories, journalistic articles on current affairs, and description of travel and daily life. Family records include information about baptisms, financial documents, health notes, letters of sympathy for the infant death of Cyril's and Sue's first daughter, school reports, and legal documents regarding a lawsuit over Cassius M. Clay, Jr.'s estate. Finally, the collection includes 119 photo negatives of family pictures, presumably from when the Goodman's lived on Stoner Avenue in Paris, Kentucky.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clavia Goodman series comprises manuscripts (short stories, poetry, and verse) and draft and notes for Bitter Harvest, a biography of Clavia's aunt and noted suffragette, Laura Clay. The series includes letters, notebooks, and papers from when Clavia attended boarding schools, Grovely Manor School, Boscombe, Bournemouth, Dorset, England and Lyngholt School, Hindhead, England in the 1910's through 1923. It also contains diaries and travel logs from 1931-1970. Lastly, the series includes two scrapbooks: one with ephemera from a trip to Austria in 1932 and another honoring murdered Austrian Chancellor Englebert Dolfuss made in 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clay family series comprise primarily letters to and from descendents of Brutus J. Clay. Clay family letters 1856-1916. One letter of note is from Brutus J. Clay to Senator Cassius M. Clay while in Washington D.C. in 1864. The series includes many letters to Cassius M. Clay, Jr. verifying the integrity of the then unknown Englisman, Cyril Goodman before the wedding of Cyril and Sue Goodman in 1901. Other letters regard a suit brought against the probate of C.M. Clay, Jr.'s will by Mary Clay Grier (1916). The series also includes many letters to Anne Clay Shacklford from family during 1890-1906.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dr. Cyril Goodman series, 1898-1939, undated, comprises the doctor's printed materials, records, and writings from his position as medical officer in Egypt and during his retirement in Kentucky. The bulk of the series includes unpublished news articles and notes written by Goodman on topics like the Anglican Church, Isle of Wight Council, and European and Egyptian culture and politics. Some of the writings were student exercises for classes at the London School of Journalism. The series also includes business papers like letters of recommendation and some financial records like school receipts. Finally, the series contains ephemera like fliers, stationary, and seating charts from life as a doctor in Egypt from 1901-1918.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Goodman family series, 1898-1964, undated, comprises letters among Clavia, Cyril, and Sue Goodman, as well as some family papers. Many of the letters are from Clavia to her parents while away at school in England and traveling. An even larger portion of the letters are between Cyril and Sue, from when they were courting and throughout their marriage. The series includes condolence cards sent to the family upon the infant death of Laurie and the death of Cyril.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sue Elizabeth Clay Goodman series, 1885-1965, undated, primarily comprises letters sent to Sue from friends and family in America, Egypt, and Europe. The letters generally discuss day to day and describe travels. Of note are letters from Anne Clay Shackleford, Sue's devoted sister. Also included are letters from Sue to her family while attending Edgeworth School for Young Ladies in Baltimore, as well as notebooks and reports. The series also contains an autograph book, memory book, and travelog from a European trip Sue took with her sister, Anne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Negatives series, undated, contains 119 photo negatives of family images of the Goodman family, presumably at their home in Paris, Kentucky. Most of the pictures are outside in the front and back yard of their house. The series also includes three portrait photographs of Dr. Cyril Goodman developed onto post cards.
